title: Viral inactivation of clinical samples

source.body:
Warning! Exposure to SARS-CoV-2 can result in COVID-19.
➢ All unsealed work must be undertaken in a class I or Class II Microbiological Safety Cabinet (MBSC).

Single sample per cycle only!
Working with multiple samples might lead to errors in sample identification!
➢ Work with only one bagged sample at a time

source.description: Remove the liquid waste container lid and place it to the side in the MBSC.
Examine the sample within the bag to ensure no leakages in the bag, on the side of the tube etc.
Check the barcodes stapled to the outer bag match the bar code on the swab vial within it.

source.body: If barcodes do not align, DO NOT PROCESS. Spray bag out at end of work to be removed and rescanned at scanning station.

source.description: Remove barcodes and place on the work area.
Take a tissue and spray with Amphospray so it is thoroughly soaked.
Spray the outer bag.
Open the outer bag and spray inside with Amphospray so inner bag is wet.
Remove inner bag and discard outer bag into the dry waste bag.
Open the inner bag.
Spray inside with Amphospray.

Open inner bag and remove sample vial by either:
a. Tipping sample onto wet tissue
b. Pinching the bottom of the sample tube through bag and scrunching up the bag to reveal the sample.

source.body: If two samples are present in one bag, take 50% of the liquid from each sample.

source.description: Wipe sample tube thoroughly with wet tissue and place into the rack.
Discard inner bag into dry waste bag.
Pick up a new inactivation tube.

Check it contains inactivation liquid.
Discard any inactivation vial that does not contain inactivation liquid into the liquid waste container.
Check provided barcodes for damage & use best-quality barcode (the others are spares).

source.body: Downstream automation will only work if the labels are orientated vertically and as straight as possible!

source.description: Stick barcode label to the inactivation tube as shown.
Place the labelled inactivation tube into the rack.
Remove swab sample from the rack.
Open swab sample lid.
Place lid into liquid waste container.

source.body: If swab is still affixed to the lid, discard into liquid waste container.

source.description: Holding the swab vial, place hands over the liquid waste container so the swab vial opening is slightly hanging above the liquid waste container to catch any drips.

source.body: Take care to not place the whole swab vial directly over the waste container in case it falls/slips/dropped accidentally.

source.description:
Draw up ~
into a fresh pastette.

source.body: Refer to example pastettes with marked 100 μl level.

source.description: Keep pastette hovering above liquid waste container.
Return sample vial to the rack.
Pick up inactivation vial.
Remove lid and either place it down or pinch between thumb and forefinger.
Dispense the pastette’s content into the bottom of the inactivation vial (to minimise bubbling).
Seal inactivation vial.

Draw up some
into the pastette.
Discard the pastette into the liquid waste container.
Wipe over inactivation vial with Amphospray-soaked paper towel.
Flick inactivation vial.
Place into Eppendorf rack.
Place open swab vial into liquid waste container.
Repeat steps 3 - 36 with the next sample.
Pick up one sample bag.
Pick up one sample bag.

source.body:
Important information regarding dry swabs!
Dry swabs will arrive in a variety of containers e.g.
  • Universal tubes with conical bottoms
  • Universal tubes with flat bottoms
  • Urine sample pot with flat bottoms
  • It is important that the SOP instructions are followed to prevent
  • Cross contamination
  • Maximise sample recovery
It is important that the SOP instructions are followed to prevent
  • Cross contamination
  • Maximise sample recovery

source.description: Examine the sample within the bag to ensure no leakages in the bag, on the side of the tube etc.
Check the barcodes stapled to the outer bag match the bar code on the swab vial within it.

source.body: If barcodes do not align, DO NOT PROCESS. Spray bag out at end of work to be removed and rescanned at scanning station

source.description: Remove barcodes and place on the work area.
Check provided barcodes for damage and use best-quality barcode (the others are spares).

source.body: The ASF robot will only work if the labels are orientated vertically and as straight as possible!

source.description:
Check the 2 ml inactivation tube contains
.
Stick the barcode label to the inactivation tube.
Place the labelled inactivation tube into the rack.
Take a tissue and spray with Amphospray so it is thoroughly soaked.
Spray the outer bag.
Open the outer bag.
Spray inside the bag with Amphospray so inner bag is wet.
Remove inner bag and discard outer bag into the dry waste bag.
Open the inner bag.
Spray the inner bag with Amphospray.

Remove sample vial by either:
a. Tipping sample onto wet tissue
b. Pinching the bottom of the sample tube through bag and scrunching up the bag to reveal the sample.
Wipe sample tube thoroughly with wet tissue and place into the rack.
Discard inner bag into dry waste bag.
Unscrew the swab container lid.
Place the lid in front of the container.

Unscrew barcoded 2 ml inactivation tube containing the
.
Draw up the lysis buffer into a fresh pastette
Aspirate the lysis buffer into opened swab vial.

Draw up some
into the pastette.
Discard the pastette into the liquid waste container.
Replace the lid on the swab container.
Agitate the swab container to ensure the swabs are in contact with the lysis buffer.
Replace the lid on the inactivation tube.
Proceed in accordance with the bottom shape of the swab pot: If the swab pot is a flat-bottomed container follow case 'flat bottom'. If the swab pot has a conical bottom follow case 'conical bottom'.
Place flat-bottomed containers on the angled rack as shown in the picture.

source.body: Maximising sample recovery from flat bottomed containers.

source.description: Make sure the pot is rotated so that the swab is sitting in the lysis buffer.
Leaving tubes two spaces apart on rack, proceed to the next sample.

Follow steps 34 - 37 only after lysis buffer has been added to last of the sample set you have taken
into the MBSC (usually this will be a set of 12 swab samples).

source.body:
All swabs must have a minimum of 10 minutes contact with the lysis buffer.
Set 10-minute timer!

source.description:
Follow steps 33 - 36 only after lysis buffer has been added to last of the sample set you have taken
into the MBSC (usually this will be a set of 12 swab samples).

source.body:
All swabs must have a minimum of 10 minutes contact with the lysis buffer.
Set 10-minute timer!

source.description: Remove over-sleeves and outer gloves.
Set the timer outside the MBSC for 10 minutes.
Outside the MBSC put on a fresh pair of outer gloves.
Outside the MBSC put on a fresh pair of over-sleeves.
Unscrew barcoded 2 ml inactivation tube.

source.body:
Working with multiple samples might lead to errors in sample identification
➢ Work with only one swab sample at a time
➢ Continue with the protocol ONLY after the 10-minute timer has sounded

source.description: Place 2 ml inactivation tube lid down to the side.
Pick up the corresponding swab container.
Check the barcodes on the swab container and opened inactivation tube match.

source.body:
Correct barcode check
➢ This is a vital check to ensure the right sample is processed back into its corresponding
inactivation tube to avoid misdiagnosis of patient samples

source.description: Once the match is verified, unscrew the swab container lid.
Discard the swab container lid into the 10% Surfanios liquid waste tub.
Holding the swab vial, place hands over the liquid waste container so the swab vial opening is slightly hanging above the liquid waste container to catch any drips.

source.body: Take care to not place the whole swab vial directly over the waste container in case it falls/slips/dropped accidentally.

source.description: Draw up the lysis buffer from the swab container into a fresh pastette.

source.body:
Important information: the dry swabs will have absorbed some of the lysis buffer
➢ Do not expect to recover the full 1 ml of lysis buffer

source.description: Dispose of the swab container into the 10% Surfanios liquid waste tub.
Dispense the pastette’s content into the bottom of the 2 ml inactivation tube (to minimise bubbling).
Reseal the 2 ml inactivation tube.

Draw up some
into the pastette.
Discard the pastette into the liquid waste container.
Replace the lid onto the 2 ml inactivation tube.

When a rack of inactivated samples is ready to be removed from the MBSC proceed to the 'Removal of
racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC' section below.

When a rack of inactivated samples is ready to be removed from the MBSC proceed to the 'Removal of
racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC' section below.
Remove over-sleeves and outer gloves.
Set the timer outside the MBSC for 10 minutes.
Outside the MBSC put on a fresh pair of outer gloves.
Outside the MBSC put on a fresh pair of over-sleeves.
Unscrew barcoded 2 ml inactivation tube.

source.body:
Working with multiple samples might lead to errors in sample identification
➢ Work with only one swab sample at a time
➢ Continue with the protocol ONLY after the 10-minute timer has sounded

source.description: Place 2 ml inactivation tube lid down to the side.
Pick up the corresponding swab container.
Check the barcodes on the swab container and opened inactivation tube match.

source.body:
Correct barcode check
➢ This is a vital check to ensure the right sample is processed back into its corresponding
inactivation tube to avoid misdiagnosis of patient samples

source.description: Once the match is verified, unscrew the swab container lid.
Discard the swab container lid into the 10% Surfanios liquid waste tub.
Holding the swab vial, place hands over the liquid waste container so the swab vial opening is slightly hanging above the liquid waste container to catch any drips.

source.body: Take care to not place the whole swab vial directly over the waste container in case it falls/slips/dropped accidentally.

source.description: Draw up the lysis buffer from the swab container into a fresh pastette.

source.body:
Important information: the dry swabs will have absorbed some of the lysis buffer
➢ Do not expect to recover the full 1 ml of lysis buffer

source.description: Dispose of the swab container into the 10% Surfanios liquid waste tub.
Dispense the pastette’s content into the bottom of the 2 ml inactivation tube (to minimise bubbling).
Reseal the 2 ml inactivation tube.

Draw up some
into the pastette.
Discard the pastette into the liquid waste container.
Replace the lid onto the 2 ml inactivation tube.

When a rack of inactivated samples is ready to be removed from the MBSC proceed to the 'Removal of
racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC' section below.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Visually inspect all the inactivation vials to ensure that all vials are capped.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Place lid loosely on liquid waste container. Dispose of all bags, barcodes and blue roll into the blue waste bag.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description:
Set up a clean area large enough for rack to sit on top of for decontamination, either:
a. Spray Amphospray onto tissue and wipe area
b. Directly spray an area on the floor of the hood

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Spray the rack thoroughly with Amphospray and place on pre-cleaned area in MBSC.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Remove existing “dirty” second gloves and over sleeves. Discard at side of MBSC.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Start 5-minute timer.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: When timer rings, remove the rack from the MBSC with clean orange or blue gloves.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Transfer completed inactivation vials to transport rack.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: If processing another set of samples, start again by collecting a fresh tub from the corridor.

source.body:
To prevent fatigue and operator error, work only in pre-arranged 1-hour shifts. If you are in the
middle of a batch, stop and hand over to the next person.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Once full, notify runner that samples are ready for collection.

source.body:
Batching of tubes for downstream automation processing
The optimal number for plate transfer is 93 tubes
➢ Fill each blue lid rack with 93 inactivated samples
➢ The final three spaces are required for one positive and two negative controls (added during later steps).

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Close box.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Spray box and transfer to corridor.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Place a [removable] tape label on the box.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Write the date and time and room on the box.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Place the rack in the transfer box and replace the lid.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Notify runners that samples are ready.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.description: Restart sample processing.

source.body:
Once a box is full to the required number of racks
a) Place a “outgoing” laminated sign on the transfer box
b) Spray and wipe the transfer box and remove it to the table in the corridor
c) Phone sample reception area to inform SHS there is a box ready for collection.

source.title: Removal of racks of inactivated samples from the MBSC

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Runners' tasks entering CL3 facility:

source.body:
Full boxes of inactivated samples will be transported from the CL2/3 to RNA extraction lab by
Health & Safety or other nominated staff (runners).

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Put on a pair of gloves in the gowning room.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Enter the inner corridor.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Put on a purple lab coat.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Go to the relevant room.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Spray the outside of the transfer box with Amphospray.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Wipe down the outside of the box with tissue.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Discard the tissue into the waste bin in the room.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Spray your gloves with Amphospray.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Leave the room with the transfer box.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Place the transfer box on the table by the exit.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Remove and hang up your lab coat.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Remove your gloves.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Dispose of the gloves in the blue autoclave bin under the table.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Take the transfer box into gowning room.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Wash your hands.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Leave the gowning room.

source.title: Movement of full transfer boxes to RNA extraction lab

source.description: Deposit the samples at the RNA extraction lab reception area.

description:
Purpose of examination / Clinical relevance
At the end of 2019, several pneumonia cases were reported in Wuhan, China and the pathogen was confirmed as a new viral strain. World Health organization has named the newly identified coronavirus as 2019-nCoV, also known as SARS-Cov-2. The disease developed into a dangerous pandemic, posing major challenges to the NHS. Although more research is necessary to better understand the virus, in response to the emergency, simple and rapid testing is essential to identify the virus in infected individuals. This will aid the implementation of efficient interventions to contain the spread, and distinguish healthcare workers who have been infected, and are required to self-isolate, from those showing similar symptoms but which are not 2019-nCoV associated. The latter category may continue to work, alleviating stress on hard-pressed healthcare resources. 2019-nCoV is an RNA virus, and the diagnostic tests detect viral RNA in swabs from patient airways using a reverse transcriptase PCR assay. Samples are submitted to HSL, an accredited reporting laboratory, and transferred to the Crick for testing. The first step of the process is sample receipt at the Crick. This SOP describes the inactivation of the virus.
